paper_metadata.title: Graduation from Ultra Poverty (GUP) Program Evaluation in Ghana

component_a_cash_support.cash_evidence_citation: While many of the program's components (e.g., consumption support) are relatively well-tested

component_b_assets.assets_evidence_citation: The GUP households are provided a productive asset (such as a cow or goats) with which they will develop their enterprise

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: Overall, the program aims to improve the incomes of the ultra-poor and hopes to see positive changes in school attendance of children, food security, health, and increased assets among the ultra-poor
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: First, it enhances the rigor of the original evaluation design by conducting a randomized trial, removing any selection biases from the comparison between groups

bonus_information.cost_mentions: Implementation and program costs of US$1,777 per household (2014 PPP US$5,408) with 133% return on investment
bonus_information.cost_evidence_citation: Researchers calculated total implementation and program costs to be US$1,777 per household (2014 PPP US$5,408). However, estimated benefits of consumption and asset growth amount to 2014 PPP US$7,175 per household, representing an overall 133 percent return on investment

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: The Graduation from Ultra Poverty (GUP) program aims to improve the economic status of the very poor and move them towards self-sufficiency in Ghana
evidence_citations.country_citation: The Graduation from Ultra Poverty (GUP) program aims to improve the economic status of the very poor and move them towards self-sufficiency in Ghana
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: The Graduation Approach is modelled as a method of enabling the ultra-poor to build businesses and improve their lives
